subtitle.Text: So that was probably the hardest one we had to record. It was actually part of the second batch of recording we did, so I had the script a few days before we did the recording, to kind of read through it all and get a feel for where the story was going,

and then we’d met for lunch to go over everything and see if I had any questions before we went into the studio. And I just right away admitted, yep, some part of this script here like, yep I will be honest, one of these totally had me crying.
Like, straight up, totally couldn’t help it. Figuring like, yeah, I had my cry out, it was good, I’ll be fine, get to the recording, it’ll be great. Ya know, get it out of your system.

And as soon as like I read the first word, I was like, no, oh god, I’m gonna start crying again, this is gonna be great. Like hey, I’m a professional voice actress in the studio, I’m gonna totally bawl all over your lines
and it’s going to sound ridiculous and terrible, and we’re going to have to do the take again, and it’s gonna sound even worse because now I’m crying…
So, it actually ended up being one take. Really… cathartic in a way, for me, I think. Because it’s, it’s really… How do I put it…
It’s really me talking to… like, specific people.
I knew it was going to happen again, I knew it, I knew it! It’s this stupid writing being so on-point!

Which is a great, I mean, you know, definite praise for the character buildup at this point, because I just become so connected with her, and making those parallels all the way along, and then you get to this point where it’s like, I know exactly how you feel. Like, I know exactly what you’re going through.

I mean it was just, it was completely authentic. I mean, I’ve enjoyed people commenting on the connection they’ve had to the emotion that’s in the character, and this is always the diary I think of, because it’s the one that most got me.
